comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: From Joyce's The Neighbourhood of Dublin from 1911 (no, not that Joyce): Orwell Bridge was formerly called " Waldron's Bridge," from the name of a former proprietor of the mills adjoining.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Here's an old photo of the saw mill including a chimney which is missing from this photo. If we knew when the chimney was removed it help dating the photo.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: I see no dogs, but [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] might like this from the 'Lost' column in Freeman's June 20 1887:

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Sad footnote related to the Sawmills from irishmedals.org Frost, William Edward, Lieutenant, 1st Bn. attd. 6th Bn. Lincolnshire Regiment aged 30 died on the 08/10/1919. Awarded the Military Medal. Frost’s body was found in a field adjoining Rathgar Saw Mills Dublin. The inquest into his death returned a verdict that he had killed himself by poison when the balance of his mind was disturbed. Frost was home on sick leave from the Army and after a telegram from the War Office his wife stated he had become excited and anxious believing he was to be court-martialled although no reason was given as to why he felt this way. Buried Commemorated, Grangegorman Military Cemetery, Dublin, Ireland.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: The weir doesn't appear to be on this 1880 map and the Sawmills are still in use at that time. Can't find any info on when the weir was built but it could be the key to dating the photo.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] The weir is certainly there in 1880, although not clear on that map. You can see the Mill Race from this weir running along just North of the Dodder to the cloth mill at Dartry. The weir was there in 1837 for the 6" map, too.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] my mistake - thanks for the clarification. Any ideas about when that chimney was removed? BTW that historical photo I posted earlier describes it as "Locke & Woods Sawmills"

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: In 1852, Thoms said: Near the Dodder, until very lately, there were calico printing works, of Messrs. Waldron, worked by steam and water-wheel power, and giving employment to a great number of persons. So Waldron's calico works was shut by 1852. Thom's did not refer to it at all in 1864, but didn't mention the sawmill, either.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: Comparing the 1880 map with the 1911 map it looks like the lighter building at the back of the Sawmills wasn't there when the 1880 map was surveyed. I've just found out though that the date of that map is an estimate and it could be anytime between 1878 and 1884. www.oldirishmaps.com/proddetail.php?prod=DubOrdSurvXL&... I think it's fair to assume that the photo above was taken after 1878 in this case.

comment.author: 30369211@N00

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content:
Winter records for Britain from www.netweather.tv/index.cgi?action=winter-history;sess=
1875-76: Amazingly snowy winter for the UK, especially the South East early on, the first week of December dumped 1-2ft in some places, worst in the South East. March of this month had many snowstorms, and April recorded nearly 2ft of snow in the Midlands! Snowfall was recorded (on a notable scale), in November, December, January, February, March, April, and May! I would regard this winter as very snowy. 1878-79: Another snowy one! In the north, snow cover remained for 3 months! Snow recorded in November, December, January, February, March and April! Very snowy 1880-81: Now I didn't add this one for the huge volume of snow it recorded (it didn't, although it was still snowy!) I added this, because of the early snowfall! 6 inches of snow fell in October in London! In January, 3ft of level snow fell from East Devon to the Isle of Wight! There were 10ft drifts in Evesham, and Dartmoor recorded 4ft. Very Snowy Interestingly, 1881-82 wasn't snowy at all!

comment.author: 35831938@N06
comment._content: Good work, wonderful white, and black

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: If I had to call it I'd say January 1881 based on the evidence of the c1880 map and the winter weather records.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/77199267@N03] Judging from this report in Freeman's of Jan 17 1881, I wouldn't disagree:
The "cold snap" as the Americans say, holds Dublin in its iron grasp, and the temperature for the past few days has been bitter beyond anything remembered, even by old inhabtants.
The article goes on to describe "frozen lobsters in warm pantries", the beautiful effect caused by a burst pipe in the north of the city, and names the various ponds and lakes where skating was taking place.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: And on the 24th, Freeman's was reporting "commodious sheets of ice here, there and everywhere". For skaters there were "torchlight arrangements for those who desired to go on after nightfall". Freeman's report 24th Jan 1881

comment.author: 77199267@N03

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: J Edmunson cashing in on the craze - Advert in Freeman's Jan 25th 1881

comment.author: 8420103@N05
comment._content: If there is only one weir between Orwell Bridge and the new downstream bridge that was built at the old stepping stones and that connected Orwell Gardens (roughly at the circle) to the other side of the river, then this is it in July 2006. Taken from the new bridge.. I lived in Orwell Gardens around 1950-54 long before the local authority paid any attention to the regular flooding in the Gardens. At that time we used to cross the river by homemade stepping stones, maintained by local communal effort. That way we could walk along the far bank to Dartry and get the No.14 bus to Rathmines or town. The new bridge was built long after I left, but I was very impressed when I went back in 2006 and saw both it and what the authorities had done to seriously upgrade the park on the other side. The authorities have provided a nice seat in the park near the bridge, and the sculptor has sculpted his phone number onto it in case you need a nice garden seat or a gravestone. If I'm wrong about the weir, feel free to delete this comment.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
